Yours is the ONLY restauration channel on Youtube that truly takes this subject seriously. A lot of so called restorers just take sh*t apart, don't really understand the intricate nature or function of a lot of the parts, and they often don't really repair stuff. The usually just take stuff apart, clean, paint it with rattle can, and put it back together. That only gets you there 85% of the way.

You Sir, you go the extra 15% and *MORE*. My hat off to your quality of workmanship and dedication. You've earned every one of the 500K subscribers! :)
Thank you!

That's very pretty and all, but really, this is hardly a "restoration". The final product bears little resemblance to the tool that left the factory. This was a tool, a functional object built to do a job - it was never intended to be a piece of art, or the fantastic object that it's become.

If this sort of thing excites you, then by all means.. but a restorer works in subtleties and always values conservation over decoration. So if you're up for a genuine challenge, next time try to perform the work without leaving a hundred year's worth of patina in the chip pile.

I love your work and do not criticize, but there is an aspect to antiques that should not be overlooked: the age. Your work is to make new tools of old – removing the stories, the history, and the sense of time from them. On the one hand, I am delighted by watching a new – perhaps better than new – tool emerge from under the rust, but I also wonder how compelling a museum would be if every mummy were rewrapped in bright white polyester and every artifact shined like new. I m left feeling somewhat melancholy by watching you work – as if some bit of the world I know has been lost.
Thats what we call: seeking perfection.

Oh nafig! So restored, why? What to put on the shelf under the glass? I do not think that Ko introduced such a soldering iron expected such a fate. "FUNERAL" He was a creator and we "Thanatocoenoses" I do not see the point so perverted.

The pure copper soldering iron should be hammered to the needed shape, and you clearly could see that it was done this way on the original soldering iron tip. It was made this way instead of rasping it to prolong it's use and prevent copper dissolving in the plumbum and tin. Hammered tip last much longer deu to hardening then hammered. Screw fixing the soldering tip will probably not whitstand hammering, that's why it was not used originally.

Overall: perfect job, good to put this soldering iron to collection. But, on my opinion, too perfect to put it in the technological museum. Original parts was not polished to shine, for example. It was a working tool, not a piece of art. But perfection get more likes on YouTube. My one goes here too :)

Gosh I keep getting blown away by every single one of his videos. The pure level of craftsmanship, genius and care that goes into every single one of them is insane.

I don't like badmouthing other channels, but way too many "restoration" channels out there don't really care about the item they're restoring. They take out some parts, wash them quickly, splash some fancy new paint on it and done to never be seen again, next one.

This guy goes so far above and beyond. He cares about and takes care of literally EVERYTHING. He takes appart his items down to the very last oh so little part and inspects and works on them with a level of skill, care and passion that that is unrivaled. He has the ability to breave new life into items that seem completely lost and broken. And if a part is broken beyond repair, he has the knowledge, craftsmanship and tools to make a replacement which isn't anything short of perfection. And the way he carefully inspects, cleans and polishes everything down to the last screw is truely a sight to behold of. It's one thing to give a rosted old item a shiny new look. It's a completely different level to understand the inner nature and little quirks of said item, getting its mechanics right and restoring it back to its original functionality, keeping the original spirit of the item alive while adding some personal and shiny new touch. And this guy completely nails it every goddam time. I also love the fact he actively uses some of his restorations in future works, they don't just vanish into a corner to be forgoten again.

The video editing shouldn't go unmentioned either. Video editing is a craft in itself, and he is an absolute master at it too. Every step he takes gets documented properly, nothing is skipped or cut out. But he also doesn't strech things out unnescecarely to the point it gets boring. The camera angles and lighting are always on point, it's like you're watching from his perspective. There is no annoying or bs narration or music, just straight to the point with only the lovely sound of machines doing their work in the background. I think the fact you can watch a 20+ min video of a guy tinkering with his stuff without any narration or music and not be bored one sec, but rather amazed, speaks for itself.

To add, it isn't just limited to the tools as a whole; literally every single part and piece, no matter how small, is given a lot of attention and care. The copper Bit needs to be tinned. That is accomplished with Sal Ammoniac and solder. You heat the Bit up and clean it on the Sal Ammoniac then use an offcut of galvanised flat iron to use as a base on which you wipe the bit on as you at the same time apply the 50/50 tin lead solder. Can also use some sulphuric acid on the gal iron to help the process along. Use fingers to flick off any excess solder.

Your restoration work is incredible, I love the care you put into everything, you truly go above and beyond almost everywhere. However, I think your wood finishing has a lot of room for improvement, I do a ton of turning/finishing. Our method for finishing something like this, a handle turned on a lathe:

Sand on lathe:
(With spindle going in reverse)
150 grit
220 grit
(With spindle going in normal direction)
150 grit
220
320
400
600

Then for finishing we use OSMO natural floor oil/wax, satin.

Apply first coat, and wipe part as dry as possible, it’s very important to get it all off.
Let sit 24 hours.
Appply second coat, also wiping completely dry.
Let sit 24 hours.
Buff on cotton buffing wheel.

This is will give you a polished and shiny finish, that will bring the grain out and elevate the woodwork on your projects to the same level as everything else. It saddens me to see such a beautiful project have a key component neglected.

Keep up the great work
